table3.Title: Auto Racing
table3.Notes: Running change with steering changed from "directional" to "realistic" (left/right).

table3.Title: Boxing ^
table3.Notes: Two players required

table3.Title: Major League Baseball ^
table3.Notes: aka Baseball, Big League Baseball;  Two players required.

table3.Title: NASL Soccer ^
table3.Notes: aka Soccer; Two players required.

table3.Title: NBA Basketball ^
table3.Notes: aka Basketball;  Two players required.

table3.Title: NFL Football ^
table3.Notes: aka Football;  Two players required.

table3.Title: NHL Hockey ^
table3.Notes: aka Hockey;  Two players required.

table3.Title: PBA Bowling
table3.Notes: aka Bowling

table3.Title: PGA Golf [5]
table3.Notes: aka Golf

table3.Title: Tennis ^
table3.Notes: Two players required. In addition to Gavin Claypool, programming credits are also given to Chris Lutz.[6]

table3.Title: U.S. Ski Team Skiing
table3.Notes: aka Skiing. In addition to Scott Reynolds, programming credits are also given to Terry Ligocki.[6]

table3.Title: Advanced Dungeons & Dragons
table3.Notes: aka Advanced Dungeons & Dragons Cloudy Mountain, Adventure, Crown of Kings; Programming by Chris Hawley, Tom Soulanille, and Tom Loughry.[7]

table3.Title: Armor Battle ^
table3.Notes: Running change with faster tank turning.  Two players required.

table3.Title: Sea Battle ^
table3.Notes: Two players required.

table3.Title: Sharp Shot
table3.Notes: designed for voice activated control for TV Powww call-in game show

table3.Title: Sub Hunt
table3.Notes: Programming by John Hershberger and Tom Loughry[7]

table3.Title: Triple Action ^
table3.Notes: album cartridge:  Battle Tanks, Racing Cars, and Biplanes;  Two players required for Biplanes and Battle Tanks.  In addition to Rich O'Keefe, programming credits are also given to Shal Farley.[8]

table3.Title: Space Battle
table3.Notes: Originally part of Action network.  Running change added a fifth "super advanced" difficulty level.

table3.Title: Star Strike
table3.Notes: Running change fixes bug with left controller.

table3.Title: ABPA Backgammon
table3.Notes: aka Backgammon

table3.Title: Checkers
table3.Notes: aka Draughts in some markets

table3.Title: USCF Chess
table3.Notes: aka Chess

table3.Title: Utopia
table3.Notes: Credited as the game that spawned the construction and management simulation genre.  For one or two players.

table3.Title: Las Vegas Poker & Blackjack
table3.Notes: aka Blackjack & Poker; pack-in game 1980-1982

table3.Title: Las Vegas Roulette
table3.Notes: Programmed by Walter Bright[9]  Intellivision Lives also credits John Brooks.

table3.Title: The Electric Company: Math Fun[10]
table3.Notes: aka Math Masters; Running change had digit entry changed from right to left to left to right.

table3.Title: The Electric Company: Word Fun[11]
table3.Notes: album cartridge:  Crosswords, Word Hunt, and Word Rockets. In addition to Kevin Miller, programming credits are also given to Don Bacon.[6]

table3.Title: Advanced Dungeons & Dragons: Treasure of Tarmin
table3.Notes: aka Minotaur

table3.Title: Masters of the Universe: The Power of He-Man
Pac-Man
table3.Notes: Later re-released by INTV Corporation.

table3.Title: Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back
Super Cobra
table3.Notes: Was not available in the United States.[14]

table3.Title: Tutankham
table3.Notes: Was not available in the United States.[14]

table3.Title: World Cup Soccer
table3.Notes: When used with the ECS Computer Adapter up-to four controllers and cooperative two-player game-play is supported.  aka Super Soccer

table3.Title: Hover Force
table3.Notes: Programmed with ChromaDepth 3-D technology[15] and shown publicly by Mattel Electronics as HoverForce 3-D at 1984 January CES.[16]  Released by INTV with modified game-play, 3-D glasses not included.[17]

table3.Title: Learning Fun I
table3.Notes: aka Factor Fun; also includes Math Master from Math Fun cartridge

table3.Title: Learning Fun II
table3.Notes: aka Memory Fun; also includes Word Rockets, Word Hunt, Crosswords from Word Fun cartridge

table3.Title: Mountain Madness: Super Pro Skiing
table3.Notes: updated U.S. Ski Team Skiing

table3.Title: Slam Dunk: Super Pro Basketball
table3.Notes: updated NBA Basketball

table3.Title: Slap Shot: Super Pro Hockey
table3.Notes: updated NHL Hockey

table3.Title: Super Pro Football
table3.Notes: updated NFL Football

table3.Title: Tower of Doom
table3.Notes: Programmed by Daniel Bass as ADVANCED DUNGEONS & DRAGONS Tower of Mystery Cartridge. Game-play and strategy was incomplete when Mattel Electronics closed in 1984.  John Tomlinson prepared the game for the 1987 INTV release.[19][20]

table3.Title: Triple Challenge .mw-parser-output .tooltip-dotted{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}*
table3.Developer: Mattel Electronics Teletape Inc. APh Technological Consulting
table3.Notes: Compilation of previously released games Chess, Checkers, and Backgammon

table3.Title: World Championship Baseball
table3.Notes: aka All-Star Major League Baseball; updated Major League Baseball

table4.Title: The Jetsons' Ways With Words[21] ‡
table4.Notes: Developed with Mattel's Educational Product Department.

table4.Title: Melody Blaster ‡
table4.Notes: designed for the Music Synthesizer piano keyboard

table4.Title: Mr. Basic Meets Bits 'N Bytes ‡
table4.Notes: runs without the ECS Computer Module with limited features

table4.Title: World Series Major League Baseball † ‡
table4.Notes: aka Super Series Big League Baseball; First sports simulation and management video-game.

table5.Title: BASIC Cassette & Cartridge[23]
table5.Notes: Based on Microsoft BASIC v2.0b for MOS 6502.[24]  Unique cartridge using one of the Keyboard Component I/O ports.

table5.Title: Conversational French §
table5.Notes: Programming credits to Mark Stroberg, Scott Bishop, Alan Blanchard, Hal Finney, Kirsi Allison, John Tomlinson, John Brooks, Jon Buss.[6]

table5.Title: Geography Challenge §
table5.Notes: Requires the BASIC cartridge.  Programmed by Don Daglow and Julie Hoshizaki in BASIC.[25]

table5.Title: Jack LaLanne's Physical Conditioning §
table5.Notes: Programming credits to Robby Butler, Tom Loughry, Hal Finney, John Brooks, Mark Stroberg.[6]

table6.Title: Adventures of TRON
table6.Notes: An Atari 2600 conversion of Mazeatron converted back to Intellivision.  Rejected by Mattel marketing.

table6.Title: Air Strike
table6.Notes: Unfinished but playable.  Rejected by Mattel marketing.  Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac

table6.Title: Brickout!
table6.Notes: Created for the Triple Action cartridge.  Dropped due to legal concerns.  Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac.

table6.Title: Chartcraft Stock Analysis §
table6.Notes: Keyboard Component cancelled. Programming credits to Jon Buss, Bill Chapman, Kevin Miller, Scott Reynolds.[6]

table6.Title: Choplifter!
table6.Notes: lacks some sound effects.

table6.Title: Deep Pockets Super Pro Pool & Billiards
table6.Notes: Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac and Intellivision for PC Volume 2

table6.Title: Doubles Tennis
table6.Notes: Ray Kaestner updated the original Intellivision Tennis with computer controlled players and support for ECS four controllers.[30]  Unrelated to Championship Tennis.[31]

table6.Title: The Flintstones' Keyboard Fun ‡
table6.Notes: Developed with Mattel's Educational Product Department.

table6.Title: Game Factory ‡
table6.Notes: Video-game construction kit.  Released in 2001 Intellivision Rocks

table6.Title: Gli Spartani Dello Spazio †
table6.Notes: Space Spartans with Italian speech; requires the unreleased International Intellivoice

table6.Title: Go for the Gold *
table6.Notes: Compilation of previously released games Skiing, Hockey, Basketball, and Boxing

table6.Title: Hockey (Pong)
table6.Notes: Created for the Triple Action cartridge.  Dropped due to legal concerns.

table6.Title: Jeanne Dixon Astrology §
table6.Notes: Keyboard Component cancelled. Programming credits to Kevin Miller, Greg Favor[6]

table6.Title: Joust[28]
table6.Notes: no known prototype found; unreleased due to market crash

table6.Title: Jungle Hunt[28]
table6.Notes: no known prototype found; unreleased due to market crash

table6.Title: King of the Mountain
table6.Notes: Lacks sound effects and only mountains 1 and 6 accessible.  Programmed by Judy Mason.  Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac.

table6.Title: Land Battle ^
table6.Notes: Two-players required.  Cancelled by marketing.  Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac.

table6.Title: League of Light
table6.Notes: Released in 2001 Intellivision Rocks.  Programmers, Russ Lieblich and Peter Kaminski,[33] switched to Commodore 64 development and released the game as Master of the Lamps in 1985.[34]

table6.Title: Les Spartiates De L'Espace †
table6.Notes: Space Spartans with French speech; requires the unreleased International Intellivoice

table6.Title: Magic Carousel †
table6.Notes: Postponed by Mattel marketing. Released in 2001 Intellivision Rocks

table6.Title: Meteor
table6.Notes: Unfinished but playable; embedded in Astrosmash.  Dropped due to legal concerns.  Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac

table6.Title: Missile Command[28]
table6.Notes: no known prototype found; unreleased due to poor playability[28]

table6.Title: Number Jumble
table6.Notes: ECS provides scratchpad work area but plays without it.  Developed with Mattel's Educational Product Department.  Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac.

table6.Title: Party Line: Blow Out
table6.Notes: Part of the Party Line album cartridge.  Released in 2004 Intellivision Lives! for Nintendo DS

table6.Title: Party Line: Hard Hat
table6.Notes: Part of the Party Line album cartridge.  Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac

table6.Title: Party Line: Space Cadet
table6.Notes: Part of the Party Line album cartridge.  Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac

table6.Title: PizzaTime[32][31]
table6.Notes: BurgerTime sequel

table6.Title: Pole Position[28]
table6.Notes: no known prototype found; unreleased due to market crash

table6.Title: Robot Rubble
table6.Notes: Released in 2001 Intellivision Rocks

table6.Title: Rocky & Bullwinkle
table6.Notes: Cancelled by new management.

table6.Title: Scarfinger
table6.Notes: Rejected by Mattel marketing.

table6.Title: Shootin' Gallery[35]
table6.Notes: Atari 2600 version sold poorly.[36]

table6.Title: Spartaner aus dem All †
table6.Notes: Space Spartans with German speech; requires the unreleased International Intellivoice

table6.Title: Spelling Challenge §
table6.Notes: Programmed by Peter Kaminski, who also worked on an unreleased Math Challenge.[37]

table6.Title: Spina the Bee
table6.Notes: aka Zzzz! Spina the Bee.  Based on a European cartoon character, popular with little girls.  Rejected by Mattel marketing.

table6.Title: Takeover ^
table6.Notes: Two-players required.  Rejected by Mattel marketing.  Released in 1998 Intellivision Lives! PC/Mac

table6.Title: Tetris
table6.Notes: Programmed by David Warhol to test new PC development system; not for release.

table8.Developer: Arnauld Chevallier, David Harley, Heather Harley
table8.Publisher: Arnauld Chevallier, David Harley, Heather Harley
